title: My crypto transaction is stuck: what actually works (and how to avoid “fee boost” scams)

friendlyUrls.anchor: AML gray zones where safe transfers look suspicious

keyQuestions: My crypto transaction is stuck — what should I do first?
How can I tell normal network congestion from a scam?
Should I pay for a transaction accelerator or fee boost?
What information is safe to share when asking for help?
What actually works: RBF, speed-up, cancel — and when?
What should I do if someone asks for a recovery fee or remote access?
quickSteps: Verify the real status in a reputable block explorer: confirmed, pending/unconfirmed, or not found.
Identify the chain rules: Bitcoin-like fee competition vs Ethereum-like nonce/gas vs networks where waiting is the only safe option.
Use only built-in wallet controls (RBF, Speed up, Cancel) — never third-party “accelerators” promoted via ads or DMs.
Ignore unsolicited “support” and refuse access requests: no seed phrase, no private keys, no keystore files, no screen sharing, no remote tools.
After confirmation, close the loop: verify balances, record the TXID/timestamps, and avoid “test transfers” that add confusion.

issueRouting.start: My transaction looks stuck or something feels off

branches.if: The TXID is not found on reputable explorers
then: Confirm you copied the correct TXID and selected the correct chain/explorer
Check whether your wallet broadcasted the transaction (some apps queue before broadcasting)
If it still doesn’t appear, consult official wallet support using safe details only

branches.if: The TX is pending/unconfirmed in the explorer
then: Compare your fee/gas to current network conditions to understand whether congestion is likely
If your wallet offers RBF/Speed up/Cancel, use only those built-in actions
If no safe replacement exists, wait and monitor confirmations — don’t send extra “test” transactions

branches.if: Someone contacts you first offering a fee boost, accelerator, or recovery service
then: Treat it as a scam attempt and do not click links or pay fees
Never share seed phrases, private keys, or grant remote access/screen sharing
Use only official support channels you already trust

riskNotes: Scammers exploit urgency: fake accelerators, fee boosts, and impersonated support are most active when a transaction is pending.
Wallet UIs can lag or misreport; treat a reputable block explorer as the source of truth for status and confirmations.
Third-party “recovery fees” don’t upgrade your on-chain transaction — they usually just transfer money to scammers.
Remote access and screen sharing can be enough to drain funds even without a seed phrase; refuse it every time.
